occurrences.line_text: That euen wilde beasts did feare his awfull sight,
Nor bands of nature, that wilde beastes restraine,
And like a wilde goate round about did chace,
Amongst wilde beastes in desert forrests bred,
Which was, that through this worlds wyde wildernes
Far hence (quoth he) in wastfull wildernesse
In wildernesse and wastfull deserts strayd,
His ship farre come from watrie wildernesse,
Fled to the wastfull wildernesse apace,
Where she did wander in waste wildernesse,
That nought but desert wildernesse shew'd all around.
In antique times was saluage wildernesse,
But with his oares did sweepe the watry wildernesse.
She fled into the wildernesse a space,
Into that wildernesse for her vnmeet,
As you in woods and wanton wildernesse
That yonder in that wastefull wildernesse
But in that wildernesse, of men forlore,
Oft from the forrest wildings he did bring,
For falsed letters and suborned wile,
He weened well to worke some vncouth wile,
Vnweeting of their wile and treason bad,
That Virgins loue to win by wit or wile,
But wrought by Clarins wile.
By Artegall, through his owne guilty wile;
His halfen eye he wiled wondrous well,
Of false Acrasia, and her wicked wiles,
But with slie shiftes and wiles did vnderminde
Yet wilfull man he neuer would forecast,
With wilfull cord, for wanting of her will;
For Gods deare loue be not so wilfull bent,
And stird you vp to worke your wilfull smarts?
Auise thee well, and chaunge thy wilfull mood,
But Impotence with her owne wilfull hands,
As one in wilfull bale for euer buried.
And wilfull want, all carelesse of her needes;
That can withhold her wilfull wandring feet;
In wilfull languor and consuming smart,
In wilfull anguish, and dead heauinesse,
Through wilfull penury consumed quight,
But if through inward griefe or wilfull scorne
For he whose daies in wilfull woe are worne,
He wilfull lost, that he before attayned.
Left to her will by his owne wilfull blame,
And yet euen then ruing her wilfull fall,
For both so wilfull were and obstinate,
She wilfully her sorrow did augment,
As did Pyrrochles, and it wilfully vnbindes.
Wilfully make thy selfe a wretched thrall,
That he so wilfully refused grace;
And wilfully him throwing on the gras,
He wilfully did cut and shape anew;
Should wilfully be into thraldome brought,
He that his sorrow sought through wilfulnesse,
Thy weaker Nouice to performe thy will,
The Eugh obedient to the benders will,
Strangle her, else she sure will strangle thee.
But wanting rest will also want of might?
Rest is their feast, and all things at their will;
Will was his guide, and griefe led him astray.
And to your mighty will. Her humblesse low
A cruell witch her cursed will to wreake,
With humble seruice to her will prepard:
Halfe mad through malice, and reuenging will,
Farre be it from your thought, and fro my will,
From raging spoile of lawlesse victors will?
Her vildly entertaines, and will or nill,
Vnder your beames I will me safely shrowd,
For with that Pagan proud he combat will that day.
With wilfull cord, for wanting of her will;
That workes it to his will, then he that it constraines.
And eke this battels end, will need another place.
That none can breath, nor see, nor heare at will,
O but (quoth she) great griefe will not be tould,
Could neuer: will to might giues greatest aid.
Or that your wisedome will direct my thought,
Assure your selfe, I will you not forsake.
No powre he had to stirre, nor will to rize.
They let her goe at will, and wander wayes vnknowne.
Which troubled once, into huge flames will grow,
Ne euer will their feruent fury slake,
But will at last be wonne with battrie long,
I that hight Treuisan (quoth he) will ride
But nor for gold nor glee will I abide
But all the good is Gods, both power and eke will.
Of God, of grace, of iustice, of free will,
As hell she hated, chast in worke and will;
But death will neuer come, when needes require.
Vnwares me wrought vnto her wicked will,
Will iudged be, and painted forgery,
The fish that once was caught, new bait will hardly bite.
In hope to win occasion to his will;
Which we farre off will here abide to vew.
With right hands plighted, pledges of good will.
His race with reason, and with words his will,
On them she workes her will to vses bad:
Where him that witch had thralled to her will,
I him recured to a better will,
My wrathfull will, and do for mercy call.
And weened well ere long his will to win,
And will be found with perill and with paine;
Perdie (said Trompart) let her passe at will,
With her, who so will raging Furor tame,
Loue that two harts makes one, makes eke one will:
One day to worke her to his will more neare,
That during life will neuer be appeasd.
To chaunge thy will, and set Occasion free,
Will die for thirst, and water doth refuse?
But he was wise, and warie of her will,
But if for me ye fight, or me will serue,
The shame and death, which will thee soone inuade?
That money can thy wantes at will supply?
Thy spouse I will her make, if that thou lust,
Yet will I not forgoe, ne yet forget
I will him reaue of armes, the victors hire,
Ne euer will it breake, ne euer bend.
May be, that better reason will asswage
Life will I graunt thee for thy valiaunce,
And all thy wrongs will wipe out of my souenaunce.
But were your will, her sold to entertaine,
Or doen you loue, or doen you lacke your will?
I will, if please you it discure, assay,
Him to succeede therein, by his last will:
She will embosome deeper in your mind,
Bridling his will, and maistering his might:
Else she will slip away, and all our drift despise.
For soone comes age, that will her pride deflowre:
His wrathfull will with reason to asswage,
Yet will I not fro mine owne loue remoue,
Ne to your Lady will I seruice done,
Giuing the bridle to her wanton will,
Scorne the faire offer of good will profest;
And win thy will: Therefore away doe dread;
My crime, (if crime it be) I will it reed.
Doe tosse, that it will stonne thy feeble braines,
Guided thy glaunce, to bring his will to pas:
Therefore submit thy wayes vnto his will,
Seruing th'ambitious will of Augustine,
Ah but will heauens fury neuer slake,
Will not long misery late mercy make,
Will bring, and shortly make you a mayd Martiall.
To passe; but maugre thee will passe or dy.
And that they might him handle more at will,
O when will day then turne to me againe,
Him kept from landing at his wished will;
If she will not, dye meekly for her sake;
Thus warreid he long time against his will,
But she her selfe, when euer that she will,
To wander through the world abroad at will,
Dy, if thou it gainesay: I will away her beare.
And now he strength gan adde vnto his will,
That went at will, withouten carde or sayle,
Her will to win vnto his wished end.
These eyes did see, that they will euer rew
Yet will I not forsake my forward way,
The which to let you weet, will further time require.
Malbecco will no straunge knights host,
A womans will, which is disposd to go astray.
But fast good will with gentle curtesyes,
To keepe vs out, in scorne of his owne will,
Then if all fayle, we will by force it win,
And sent close messages of loue to her at will.
Who louers will deceiue. Thus was the ape,
That who from East to West will endlong seeke,
What fortune and his fate on him will lay,
And to thy will abuse? Thou walkest free,
But that continuall battery will riue,
And lacke of reskewes will to parley driue;
And Peece, that vnto parley eare will giue,
Will shortly yeeld it selfe, and will be made
Will shortly yeeld it selfe, and will be made
The vassall of the victors will byliue:
And with fowle force vnto his will did driue,
My Lord and I will search the wide forrest.
Hence farre away we will blindfolded lie,
And by no meanes would to his will be wonne,
All for she Scudamore will not denay.
At least it faire endeuour will apply.
I will with proofe of last extremity,
With greedy will, and enuious desire,
Where let them wend at will, whilest here I doe respire.
Therefore I will their sweatie yokes assoyle,
His will she feard; for him she surely thought
Will chalenge yond same other for my fee:
Ye will me now with like good turne repay,
Your selfe for this, my selfe will for you fight,
Ne will enforced be with maisterdome or might.
I saw him haue your Amoret at will,
All things not rooted well, will soone be rotten.
But not so easie will I her forsake;
Which she by art could vse vnto her will,
The which for length I will not here pursew,
But rather will reserue it for a Canto new.
As Ioue will haue aduaunced to the skie,
To let them passe at will, for dread of shame.
And then it shall be tried, if ye will,
Which Braggadocchio seeing, had no will
Where I with sound of trompe will also rest a whyle.
That fairest is and from her faith will neuer swerue.
Some baser metall, which commend he will
And will to none her maladie impart?
Or wreake on him her will for so great iniurie.
Nathlesse her tongue not to her will obayd,
Which being knit with vertue, neuer will remoue.
Relent the rigour of your wrathfull will,
And wonne her will to suffer him depart;
Were long to tell; therefore I here will stay
And of vs three to morrow he will sure eate one.
Time to my will, and from his wrathfull sight
Yet will not he the louely spoile downe lay,
I will deferre the end vntill another tide.
That will not vse his gifts for thanklesse nigardise.
Whose looser thought will lightly be misled,
These gentle Ladies will misdeeme too light,
For ought will from his greedie pleasure spare:
And at his will may whom he list restore,
Who thereto did with readie will consent,
Whose will her weakenesse could no way represse,
Ye will recount to vs in order dew
Comprised be, I will them in another tell.
That to disloyalty she will not be allured.
But since ye so desire, your will be donne.
With murmure soft, that seem'd to serue the workmans will.
Him from his wicked will vneath refrayned;
Who sore against his will did him retaine,
Vnto an other Canto I will ouerpas.
I will them tell though vnto no man neare:
Will yeeld, but when my piteous plaints he heares,
Yet will I neuer of my loue repent,
And though vnto his will she giuen were,
They into that ere long will be degendered.
That makes me feare in time he will vs quite forsake.
So ye will sweare my iudgement to abide.
It will be at the Castle of the strond;
What time if naught me let, I will be there
Then doth he take the spoile of them at will,
None other way will I this day betake,
Therefore I will throw downe these mountaines hie,
I will thrust downe into the deepest maine,
I will suppresse, that they no more may raine;
And all the wealth of rich men to the poore will draw.
Ne any may his mighty will withstand;
For by no meanes the false will with the truth be wayd.
For they with wrong or falshood will not fare;
Who so vpon him selfe will take the skill
Not wronging any other by my will,
I hold mine owne, and so will hold it still.
But I will it defend, whilst euer that I may.
The worke of heauens will surpasseth humaine thought.
Then sith ye needs (quoth he) will know my shame,
I shortly will to you rehearse the same,
In hope ye will not turne misfortune to my blame
For ought or nought be wonne vnto her will,
Any her proud obseruaunce will withstand,
I will not rest, till I her might doe trie,
How Fortune will your ruin'd name repaire,
Tell, that to morrow I with him will fight,
And so will I, if me he vanquish may,
But he that helpe from her against her will discarded.
But ruth of beautie will it mollifie.
The foolish Kyte, led with licentious will,
Left to her will by his owne wilfull blame,
That will not take the offer of good hope,
Certes Clarinda, not of cancred will,
I will a while with his first folly beare,
Who will not stoupe with good, shall be made stoupe with harme.
But like a rebell stout I will him vse.
Till I the conquest of my will recouer.
Which in an other Canto will be best contayned.
Some men, I wote, will deeme in Artegall
To th'insolent commaund of womens will;
That I would hide, will needs, I see, be rad.
And then she in her wrathfull will did cast,
With froward will doth set him selfe to weepe;
My heart at first betrayd, will ye betray
Ye will not watch? false watches, wellaway,
Vnto your losse: and now needes will ye sleepe?
Now will ye sleepe? ah wake, and rather weepe,
I will not seeke the same from you to hide,
But will my cares vnfolde, in hope to find
That for another Canto will more fitly fall.
Vntill they both doe heare, what she to them will say.
Which if ye please forgiue, I will therefore
Of whom we may at will the whole occasion know.
For neither will one foot, till we that carle haue hent.
And dauncing on the craggy cliffes at will;
Which from iust verdict will for nothing start,
If not, we will it force, maugre your foe,
Her mind so well, that to his will she bends
Yet at the last she will her owne cause right.
That your victorious arme will not yet cease,
Which will her cause in battailous array
Or with her owne good will, I cannot read aright.
And deeme it doen of will, that through inforcement came.
Why then will ye, fond Dame, attempted bee
He will not bide the daunger of such dread,
Agreeing in bad will and cancred kynd,
Ye will them all but fayned showes esteeme,
Who executes her wicked will, with worse despight.
Will it auenge, and pay thee with thy right:
In lustlesse wise, as if against his will,
Who will not mercie vnto others shew,
I will it graunt, your hopelesse life to saue;
With these conditions, which I will propound:
Sayd then Sir Calidore; Neither will I
I will the truth discouer, as it chaunst whylere.
To you I will not feare it to relate.
That ye will make me Squire without delay,
My selfe will beare a part, coportion of your packe.
That gentle bloud will gentle manners breed;
Yet if he needes will fight, craue leaue till morne,
Ne from his currish will awhit reclame.
Will full intent him cruelly to kill;
Flying the fury of his bloudy will.
Sith then ye needs will know the griefe I hoord,
Yet will it shew some sparkes of gentle mynd,
That ye will not your wrath vpon him wreake,
From your owne will, to cure your maladie.
Who can him cure, that will be cur'd of none?
Abstaine from pleasure, and restraine your will,
And layd at him amaine with all his will and might.
For well she knew the wayes to win good will
That all your other praises will deface,
I will them soone acquite, and both of blame assoile.
But Fortune did not with his will conspire.
My life will by his death haue lamentable end.
Yet no lesse thankes to you for your good will.
Where none is nigh to heare, that will her rew,
Ne any will had thence to moue away,
For some, that hath abundance at his will,
Good will and fauour. So it surely wrought
The which as commeth now, by course I will declare.
That thence, he had no will away to fare,
To serue the vengeaunce of his wrathfull will;
That at the last vnto his will he brought her;
Will in an other Canto better be begonne.
Vnto his lust, and make his will his law,
Or rise against the remnant at their will;
Who all this while at will did range and raine,
Against his will fast bound in yron chaine,
Willd him to stay, and signe of truce did make:
But whether willed or nilled friend or foe,
And willed him with Artegall to wend,
That she his fury willed him to slake:
And willed him for to reclayme with speed
And willed streight the slaues should forth be called,
So diff'ring both in willes, agreed in fine:
And to your willes both royalties and Realmes
That to their willes could them direct aright,
That from reuenge their willes they scarse asswag'd:
The knights were willing all things to excuse,
Did yield himselfe right willing to prolong his date.
Whom when so willing Artegall perceaued;
Which there did wayte, willing them forth to call
Willing him wend vnto the Tyrant streight,
Willing to worke his villenous intent
He glad of life, and willing eke to wreake
That further, then she willing was, he prest;
Is it not better to doe willinglie,
So willingly she came into his armes,
Who her as willingly to grace did take,
Sweete is the loue that comes alone with willingnesse.
The Willow worne of forlorne Paramours,
To win a willow bough, whilest other weares the bayes.
Vnto their wils, and one eyes watch escape;
Or cruelly does wound, whom so she wils:
Why wilt not let him passe, that long hath stood
Vpon the banke, yet wilt thy selfe not passe the flood?
If in true ballance thou wilt weigh thy state:
Now therefore, if thou wilt enriched bee,
Yet if thou wilt renounce thy miscreaunce,
Sith then (said Braggadocchio) needes thou wilt
Wilt giue thy beard, though it but little bee?
Himselfe wilth salues to health for to restore,
And widow-like sad wimple throwne away,
Vnder a vele, that wimpled was full low,
Resolv'd in minde all suddenly to win,
(Quoth then that aged man;) the way to win
With him away, but yet could neuer win
Both seemde to win, and both seemde won to bee,
What not by right, she cast to win by guile,
There waiting long, to win the wished sight
Where both do fight alike, to win or yield?
And win rich spoile of ransackt chastetee.
Both hungred after death: both chose to win, or die.
So hardly he the flitted life does win,
Yet neuer any could that girlond win,
All those great battels, which thou boasts to win,
In hope to win occasion to his will;
To tell this ruefull tale; thy sight could win thee grace.
In hope to win more fauour with his mate,
And weened well ere long his will to win,
That mote him honour win, to wreake so foule despight.
Their king, and swore him fealty to win or loose.
In hope thereof to win victorious spoile.
Nought feard their force, that fortilage to win,
Her selfe pursewd, in hope to win thereby
Achilles armes, which Arthegall did win.
And win thy will: Therefore away doe dread;
Thrise shall he fight with them, and twise shall win,
And win him worship through his warlike deed,
Whether more happie were, to win so goodly pray.
Which darknesse shall subdew, and heauen win;
Ne how to win the wished victory,
Her will to win vnto his wished end.
Then if all fayle, we will by force it win,
To win faire Leda to his louely trade:
Also to win Deucalions daughter bright,
That did her win and free from chalenge set:
That none the same may easily out win;
To win a willow bough, whilest other weares the bayes.
That might her loue prepare, and liking win theretoo.
That shall you win more glory, then ye here find gaines.
Where beauties prize shold win that pretious spoyle:
That many wish to win for glorie vaine,
To win her grace his libertie to get.
That Virgins loue to win by wit or wile,
That she might win some time, though dearly bought
Threw many threats, if they the towne did win,
Weening at last to win aduantage new;
To which if thou canst win him any way,
Make meanes to win thy libertie forlorne,
But that swift Talus did the formost win;
Did win the shore, whence he them chast away,
And sought to win his loue by all the meanes she might.
That euen in the Porch he him did win,
For well she knew the wayes to win good will
And washeth Winborne meades in season drye.
His sweatie forehead in the breathing wind,
Puft vp with emptie wind, and fild with sinfull crime.
That with the wind it did him ouerthrow,
Long tost with stormes, and bet with bitter wind,
Her dried dugs, like bladders lacking wind,
And with his winged heeles did tread the wind,
Till merry wind and weather call her thence away.
Vaine-glorious man, when fluttring wind does blow
The Northerne wind his wings did broad display
Each trembling leafe, and whistling wind they heare,
Or winged canuas with the wind to flie,
So easie is, t'appease the stormie wind
Ne care, ne feare I, how the wind do blow,
Whom neither wind out of their seat could forse,
Ne wind and weather at his pleasure call:
The wind vnstable, and doth neuer stay.
And with forst wind the fewell did inflame;
And wind his horne vnder the castle wall,
Till the fierce Northerne wind with blustring blast
But let them pas, whiles wind and weather right
Whe[n] the wroth Western wind does reaue their locks;
For as the winged wind his Tigre fled,
For not one puffe of wind there did appeare,
Now soft, now loud, vnto the wind did call:
The gentle warbling wind low answered to all.
But let vs hence depart, whilest wether serues and wind.
To aske this Briton Mayd, what vncouth wind,
But saile withouten starres gainst tide and wind:
Ne the sharp Northerne wind thereon to showre,
He forth issew'd; like as a boistrous wind,
Yet stoupt he not, but lay still in the wind,
As if the wind him on his winges had borne,
Was alwaies flitting as the wauering wind,
For he their words as wind esteemed light.
Me hether brought with him, as swift as wind,
And flew away, as lightly as the wind:
And breathed forth with blast of bitter wind;
That with the wind, contrary courses sew,
If wind and tide doe change, their courses change anew.
And one of th'ayre, without or wind, or wether:
And sent her winged thoughts, more swift then wind,
That ouersprad her like a puffe of wind;
Like scattred chaffe, the which the wind away doth fan.
Mixt with a murmuring winde, much like the sowne
And when the winde emongst them did inspyre,
That as the winde ran vnderneath his lode,
Murmure of winde, her terror hath encreast;
With that, an hideous storme of winde arose,
Like to the Northren winde, that none could heare:
With winged feete, as nimble as the winde;
And sailers saue from wreckes of wrathfull winde.
But Talus, that could like a limehound winde her,
And weigh the winde, that vnder heauen doth blow;
The winde and weather serued them so well,
Is met of many a counter winde and tyde,
Whom raging windes threatning to make the pray
Birdes, voyces, instruments, windes, waters, all agree.
And all his windes Dan Aeolus did keepe,
Then he by cunning sleights in at the window crept.
So soone as heauens window shewed light,
She to a window came, that opened West,
Forth of her window as she looking lay,
Ne lightned was with window, nor with louer,
Would to his hope a windowe open wyde,
Full of faire windowes, and delightfull bowres;
And shut vp heauens windowes shyning wyde:
The windowes of bright heauen opened had,
Thou God of winds, that raignest in the seas,
Sends forth the winds out of his hidden threasure,
Thee goddesse, thee the winds, the clouds doe feare,
With windy Nitre and quick Sulphur fraught,
As when a windy tempest bloweth hye,
